column1: MUS 106 - Introduction to African American Music
column3: This course offers a broad overview of black music in the U.S., spanning from its African genesis to the contemporary era. While there is a significant historical component to this course, the focus is on critically engaging with the aesthetics, the compositional formats, and the performance methodologies of various iterations of African-American music in a way that furthers our understanding of the concept of black music in America.

A group class in guitar skills is for non-music majors with limited-or-no prior guitar study. By the end of elementary guitar, students will be able to play scales, arpeggios, chords, and simple two-voice pieces. Students will also develop sight reading, analytical, and listening skills.

An introduction to coding as both a technical and creative practice, positioning programming as an art form that merges audio and visual elements. Students will work with P5.js and the Web Audio API to develop interactive multimedia projects that challenge conventional boundaries between sound and visual design. The course emphasizes open-ended experimentation and interdisciplinary collaboration, welcoming students from diverse fields such as Art, Music, and Computer Science. With no prior coding experience required, this course provides an accessible entry point for those eager to explore the creative possibilities of programming.

column1: MUS 207 - Introduction to Music Performers and Performance
column3: Serves as an introduction to a multiplicity of music performance options by offering two-week modules with various artists from the performance faculty.  They will talk about what they do as performers, how they do it, and what they think potential music majors should hear and read to pique their curiosity further.

column1: MUS 324 - Harmonic Foundations of American Popular Music I
column3: This course focuses on harmonic practices in American popular music, broadly understood (e.g., genres such as jazz, blues, rock, country, funk, and hip hop). We will take a practical, hands-on approach, learning through the transcription and analysis of performances that have shaped these musical traditions. A coordinated listening lab will develop aural skills through singing and improvisation.

column1: MUS 325 - Harmonic Foundations of American Popular Music II
column3: . As such it develops further knowledge of harmonic practices in American popular music, broadly understood (e.g., genres such as jazz, blues, rock, country, funk, and hip hop). We will take a practical, hands-on approach, learning through the transcription and analysis of performances that have shaped these musical traditions. A coordinated listening lab will develop aural skills through singing and improvisation.

column1: AAS 214 - Culture and Communication for Korean I
column3: Designed for students who have a basic knowledge of the Korean language and wish to deepen their understanding of Korea through bridging language and cultural insights. The course covers a variety of cultural topics through activities, tasks and real-life interactions that are designed to enhance their engagement in intercultural understanding and communication skills in Korean.

column1: AAS 314 - Culture and Communication for Korean II
column3: Designed for students who have a basic knowledge of the Korean language and wish to deepen their understanding of Korea through bridging language and cultural insights. The course covers a variety of cultural topics through activities, tasks and real-life interactions that are designed to enhance their engagement in intercultural understanding and communication skills in Korean.

In this project-based workshop we’ll learn about and then explore documentary theatre techniques to create and tell stories about actual events and real people. We’ll select a topic, conduct interviews, and then use those interviews to collaboratively create a script for archival purposes and for performance. Covers the Genre or Media topic for the English major.

This course offers a comprehensive introduction to Python programming with a focus on its applications in data science and financial data analytics. Students will learn the fundamentals of Python programming and how to recover and manipulate financial data. Building on this foundation, students will then explore practical applications in finance. Students will have hands-on experience applying Python to both data science and financial tasks.

This course equips students with essential personal finance management knowledge and techniques. Through lectures and discussions, students will develop analytical skills crucial for effective financial decision-making. Topics covered include budgeting, debt management, investments, insurance, retirement, and estate planning. By the end of the course, students will possess the practical knowledge necessary to make informed personal financial decisions, enabling them to adapt to changing economic conditions and work towards long-term financial stability.

Like humans, marine and terrestrial organisms use sound for a wide variety of purposes including: communication, reproduction, and foraging. This course will introduce students to the: basic physics of acoustics, principles of sound propagation in water and air, use of passive and active acoustics by animals, sound production and reception mechanisms, the effects of anthropogenic activities on the ecological soundscape, and how acoustic methods can be used to study animal behavior and ecology.

Training in reporting, writing, and producing broadcast sports stories, from event coverage and news to behind-the-scenes issues that resonate in the world of sports. Students will learn about the various roles in game-day productions of live sporting events, content creation, and social media in sports. Students will practice covering sporting events and breaking sports news stories. This course also introduces students to the challenges and opportunities that are unique to covering sporting events.

An introduction on how to (and how not to) use generative artificial intelligence (AI) to create media. This course explores the roots of creativity, art, and the relationship of technology to culture and expression. Focus is placed on learning how generative AI works, how it is constructed, how it produces what it does, and what opportunities and limitations it brings. Students will use generative AI as a tool to explore creative self-expression to communicate ideas across media, and explore the use of creative tools through time, from the canvas to the printing press, to film and recording devices, and now the computer and AI. The course will also cover problems related to AI, including cultural bias, race, power, and questions of safety. Students will get hands-on experience with various tools of generative AI, receive demonstrations of how artists are using them, and hear from expert guests.

An exploration into how to produce content and speak to a particular audience in a studio production setting. Students will work as a team to produce a news and informational show that airs during halftime at SBU athletic sporting events. Students will have a chance to explore all the roles of a studio production and/or concentrate on a particular role to boost their experience. Students will choose a role such as producer, writer, on air talent, graphics, video recording and producing in the field, or editing and studio operation. Students will also learn to conduct a short interview segment.

Work with a faculty member as an assistant in one of the faculty member’s regularly scheduled courses. The student must attend all classes and carry out tasks assigned by the faculty member to assist in teaching the course. The student will meet with the instructor on a regular basis to discuss intellectual and pedagogical matters relating to the course. Not for major or minor credit.

Work with a faculty member as an assistant in one of the faculty member’s regularly scheduled courses. The student must attend all classes and carry out tasks assigned by the faculty member to assist in teaching the course. The student will meet with the instructor on a regular basis to discuss intellectual and pedagogical matters relating to the course. Not for major or minor credit.

column1: BME 314 - Embedded Technologies in Medical Devices
column3: The course is directed to the essential technologies commonly used in embedded and wearable medical devices. There are two major modules, the digital circuit design and microcontroller. Hands-on projects will be done throughout the course to enhance learning. The digital circuit design module will teach the basics of combinational logic circuits and sequential logic circuits. The course will use myRIO platform to teach the students to design logic circuits and implement them on a Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA). The microcontroller module will teach the architecture of microcontrollers and their peripheral interfaces. Focus will be on the UART, I2C and SPI buses and the knowledge will be reinforced through projects using the myRIO embedded system kit. The course will also teach Bluetooth technology widely used in wearable devices. At the end of the course, the student will master the knowledge of embedded technologies for the applications in medical devices.

column1: CSE 213 - Foundations of Computer Science II
column3: A continuation of CSE 113 covering the mathematical foundations of computer science. Topics include counting techniques, graph theory, and finite automata.

column1: MAR 107 - Marine Organisms in Changing Oceans
column3: This course examines the impact of climate change and other human-induced changes on marine ecosystems, exploring how organisms, from microplankton to charismatic megafauna, respond and adapt to shifting ocean conditions. The course covers broad topics in marine biology and ecology, including human activities such as fisheries and offshore wind development, while preparing students for advanced and specialized studies in biological oceanography, marine ecology, evolutionary biology, fisheries science and management, and marine conservation biology.

This course explores the principles and practices of effective data communication, emphasizing clarity, accuracy, and audience-tailored design. Students will gain hands-on experience with common visualization software while learning to critique and select appropriate visualization techniques for different datasets. The course will also focus on applying ethical standards in data representation and on storytelling techniques to present data in coherent narratives. By the end of the course, students will be equipped to create impactful visualizations and to communicate data clearly and responsibly in professional settings.

column1: BME 206 - Science Fiction or Inclusive Bioengineering Solutions
column3: Our world is constantly changing with new biomedical technology and innovation driven by history specific problems (e.g., COVID-19), new technology opportunities and discrete events.  As scientists, engineers, entrepreneurs/corporate and policy makers work together to make science fiction come to life, it is important to not only understand the technology (TECH) involved but also respect diversity and foster inclusiveness (DIV).   Using multimedia (e.g., books, movies and shows), students will explore what science fiction means to us and healthcare in the near future.  Students will learn from the TECH and the DIV sides to critically think about what we could do cautiously going forward.  We will cover examples including, but not limited to, genetic engineering (cloning, CRISPR-CAS9), bioinformatics, neuroscience, machine learning/AI, tissue engineering, computer-brain interface, bioprinting, augmented reality, wearable health technology and so on.  Also, students will learn about how the review and approval process of the Institutional Review Board (IRB), FDA and patent play a crucial role in these issues.

Focused on transportation planning as an aspect of civil engineering. Covered topics include fundamentals of transportation planning, geography of transportation, impact of land use on travel behavior and mode choice, accessibility and equity in transportation, freight transportation, four-step transportation demand modeling, energy and environmental impacts of transportation activities. The course also includes individual reading and presentation assignments and class projects on contemporary issues in transportation planning.

This course explores the fundamental principles of subsurface space utilization, aiming to equip students with the knowledge and skills to conduct the analysis and design of tunnels, shafts and other subsurface infrastructure. The course has three major components: subsurface geology and geomaterial characterization, subsurface structure analysis and design and construction methods. The course will also cover safety measures and monitoring for the operation of tunnels, as well as an introduction to new types of subsurface infrastructure, such as gas storage and geothermal.

column1: ESE 335 - Offshore Wind Power System Analysis and Control
column3: This course provides a comprehensive foundation for the analysis, operation, and control of offshore wind (OSW) power systems. It covers essential topics such as OSW system modeling, static, dynamic, and transient analysis of OSW grids, and simulation techniques for large-scale OSW networks. Students will also be exposed to the unique challenges associated with integrating offshore wind into power grids, including stability, reliability, and efficiency considerations, as well as the advanced control and protection strategies for maintaining OSW system resilience. Through a combination of theoretical study and practical simulation exercises, students will develop the skills needed to analyze and optimize OSW power systems for real-world applications.

column1: ESE 351 - Power Electronics Devices Circuits and Applications
column3: An introduction to power electronics at its fundamental level, including power devices, gate drive, basic topologies, modulation and their applications.

The course focuses on High Voltage Direct Current (HVDC) and HVDC based integration of clean energy. Topics include: current source converters (CSC) HVDC, voltage source converters (VSC)-HVDC, multi-terminal HVDC, and clean energy integration through VSC-HVDC.

column1: BIO 209 - Fundamentals of Scientific Inquiry in the Biological Sciences IIC
column3: , this course focuses on disciplinary core ideas and science practices foundational to empirical and theoretical inquiry in the fields of ecology, evolutionary biology, and cognate biological disciplines. BIO 209 is the second course in the foundational laboratory sequence for all biology majors and students in related fields. Students will experience the laboratory process, research process, a wide range of laboratory tools, methods, and skills, learn to read and write scientific works, and collaborate in formal inquiry. This course has been designated as a High Demand/Controlled Access (HD/CA) course. Students registering for HD/CA courses for the first time will have priority to do so. Not for credit in addition to BIO 205 or

This course showcases for students multiple disciplinary approaches to a contemporary societal challenge through invited lectures from faculty across Stony Brook departments and colleges. The course prepares students to develop transdisciplinary skills in future courses by first introducing them to how individual researchers’ fields of study articulate with, approach, or seek to address contemporary societal challenges or themes.

This course is the first in a series of two creativity seminars centered around solution-focused approaches to a contemporary societal challenge or theme. The course bridges scholarly work and real-world applications. Students will examine a pressing social challenge or theme and will generate ideas and solutions to address this challenge. Ideas Lab I focuses on the development of the transdisciplinary mindset and individual voice.
May be repeated as topics change.

This course is the second in a series of two creativity seminars centered around solution-focused approaches to a contemporary societal challenge or theme. The course bridges scholarly work and real-world applications. Students will examine a pressing social challenge or theme and will generate ideas and solutions to address this challenge. Ideas Lab II focuses on the practice of transdisciplinary problem-solving through teams and group work.
Honors Experiences enrich and extend student learning through innovative pedagogies, independent study, structured internships, and other experiential education opportunities.

The Social Impact Capstone is the second in a series of two courses that serve as a culminating academic requirement in the Honors College Program. Students will employ transdisciplinary thinking and problem-solving to articulate ideas and solution(s) to the researched societal challenge or theme examined in the Social Analysis Capstone. Students will develop a plan for addressing the presenting challenge or theme, which may include specific action items. The Capstone concludes with a public presentation of findings and/or real-world deliverables. Students may engage with community partners and organizations as part of the course.

The Social Analysis Capstone is the first in a series of two courses that serve as a culminating academic requirement in the Honors College. Students will identify and analyze a contemporary societal challenge or theme through research and consultation and will synthesize findings with earlier coursework and transdisciplinary thinking to arrive at a nuanced understanding of the presenting challenge or theme. Students engage with community partners and organizations as part of the course.

This interdisciplinary course provides a solid foundation for students aspiring to lead with authenticity, integrity, and effectiveness. Students will learn leadership theories and concepts, as well as evidence-based skills that enable them to lead in any industry.  Students will increase self-awareness of their own leadership experiences, attributes, values, and goals and will begin to articulate a personal definition and philosophy of leadership, to include social awareness and responsibility.

Students will analyze and discuss effective leadership in practice through case studies and contemporary local and global issues.  Leadership practice will be examined through ethical reasoning and decision-making, as well.  Course topics may include leading change, innovation, team development, community engagement, communications, motivation, and ethical leadership. Students will have opportunities to apply and demonstrate their leadership knowledge and skills through projects.

The Scholars Senior Capstone serves as the culminating academic requirement in the University Scholars Program.  The course provides students with opportunities to synthesize and reflect on their academic learning, leadership knowledge, and program experiences with their professional plans and goals.  Students also will analyze and discuss leadership concepts at an advanced level, incorporating diverse and interdisciplinary perspectives, and be able to articulate a personal leadership philosophy.

What makes information biased or credible? Can you determine what information is fake or not? This course will introduce students to information literacy concepts while acknowledging the inherent bias of information. This course will ask students to challenge the preconceived notions of authoritativeness and trustworthiness of sources and learn how to critically evaluate them. Students will learn about the harms and biases perpetuated through the scholarly communication channels. Key concepts covered will include: information privilege, epistemic injustice, and citation justice. This is an interdisciplinary course that will draw from the fields of information science, archival studies, philosophy, and media studies.

The ideological and social background of the Russian Revolution and the evolution of Soviet rule: the problem of industrialization, the relations with the capitalist West, and totalitarian control over society.

column1: HIS 219 - Introduction to Chinese History and Civilization
column3: Introductory survey examining key concepts and significant themes in Chinese history. Topics include Confucianism, popular religion, government, foreign policy, the economy, Western influence, Chinese revolution, and modernization.

Students work under real deadlines for local news outlets producing print and digital news and feature stories. Students will work with local Long Island editors and the instructor to brainstorm story ideas and create assignments to be covered primarily off campus for publication. Students will switch editing and reporting roles during the semester.

column1: CIS 102 - Pop Up: AI and You
column3: This interdisciplinary course introduces students to artificial intelligence (AI) and its applications. Students will gain an understanding of AI’s potential, its limitations, and strategies for effectively engaging with AI tools. Case studies in (for example) persuasion and communication, climate science, creative arts (fine art, music, etc.), computer science, and social sciences will demonstrate the broad societal impact of AI. The course encourages critical thinking about both the potential of AI and the challenges imposed by AI in shaping our future.

This course is designed for students who engage in a substantial, structured experiential learning activity in conjunction with another class. Experiential learning occurs when knowledge acquired through formal learning and past experience are applied to a “real-world” setting or problem to create new knowledge through a process of reflection, critical analysis, feedback and synthesis. Beyond-the-classroom experiences that support experiential learning may include: service learning, mentored research, field work, or an internship.

Individually supervised readings in selected topics in Arabic language and literature or, alternatively, for the purpose of developing Arabic vocabulary in a secondary field, in selected topics in the humanities, social sciences, or natural sciences. May be repeated.

column1: ARB 475 - Undergraduate Teaching Practicum I (in Arabic)
column3: Each student conducts a regular problem or tutorial section that supplements a regular language course under the guidance of a master teacher. Responsibilities may include preparing materials for discussion and helping students with problems. Not for major or minor credit.

column1: ARB 476 - Undergraduate Teaching Practicum II (in Arabic)
column3: Work with a faculty member as an assistant in one of the faculty member’s regularly scheduled classes.  Students assume greater responsibility in such areas as leading discussions and analyzing results of tests that have already been graded. The course in which the student is permitted to work as a teaching assistant must be different from the course in which he or she previously served.
Participation in local, state, national, and international public and private agencies and organizations to apply and reinforce language skills and knowledge of social and cultural institutions.

column1: POL 402 - Advanced Seminar in Political Psychology
column3: Intensive seminar exploring topics in political psychology, covering areas such as: public opinion, political ideology, political mobilization, social movements, persuasion and propaganda, moral politics, and others. May be repeated as the topic changes.
